Hello Evert-

This is a bit belated, but I just want to agree with you that you have an
interesting initial research project. My original instincts were to go with
a monolithic controller, such as the one Ken suggested, but you may be right
that you could get a really cool and scalable solution the way you proposed.
I look forward to hearing how it turns out!

Good luck with the investigation.
-Jeff  

> As to developing a controller modularly or monolithically,  I hadn't
> considered the monolithic approach yet, and it bears thinking about. My
> intuition (I have liottle more to go on right now) is that  keeping them
> separate may promote a CPPN for scaleable morphologies (e.g., spiders with
> legs of varying length) - that would be very nice to have. Also, a modular
> approach might adapt controllers more easily when body shapes change. On the
> other hand, it's just intuition and the same may be true for the monolithic
> approach. Hmmm....sounds like a little project right there. See if I can find
> a Masters student somewhere ;)
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>> 
>> Evert, sounds like a great project.  I think there is enough precedent for
>> step 1 that it could be realistically achieved.  Of course, step 2 is more
>> speculative.
>> 
>> For step 1, my question is whether it is necessary to regard the individual
>> robots that make up the full organism as being separate for the purposes of
>> evolving the controller?  That is, would it not work to simply regard it as a
>> single whole and ignore the individual separations?  That way you could just
>> evolve one monolithic controller for the assembly.
> However, I can imagine that it might not be possible to do that depending on
> your communication constraints.  In any case, HyperNEAT can represent it
> either way.  If the identity of each robot matters, you can certainly input
> the location along the organism to the CPPN as additional information, and
> that could indeed be helpful.
>> 
>> Step 2 (evolving the morphology) sounds very interesting butis a much more
>> open problem.  I think interleaving might be more effective than simply doing
>> a meta-search in which every potential morphology is evaluated through an
>> entire evolution run to find a controller for it.  That sounds very
>> expensive.  After all, in nature both brain and body evolve together so
>> presumably it can happen here too.
>> 
>> Also, the representation of the morphology (i.e. how it is translated from
>> the CPPN output) will be very critical and deserves careful thought.
>> 
>> ken
>> 
>> 
>> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "evertwh2004" <evert@> wrote:
>>> 
>>> Hi all,
>>> 
>>> I am involved in a modular robotics project (www.symbrion.eu), where we are
>>> developing robots that can hook onto each other to create 'organisms' that
>>> consist of linked robots. The robots can manipulate the link(s), e.g., to
>>> lift each other. Recently, Jeff Clune (hi Jeff) introduced me to hyperNEAT,
>>> and it looks like just the ticket to address two issues that we have to
>>> tackle. So here I am, excited newbie and all.
>>> 
>>> First, I want to try and use hyperNEAT to evolve gaits for organisms with
>>> pre-defined shapes (e.g., spiders, snakes). The idea is to develop a single
>>> genome that determines the weights for neural nets in each of the individual
>>> robots that make up the organism, so I would expect to pass the coordinates
>>> of nodes within the individual NN, but also about the location of the
>>> individual in the organism (possibly related to some central node or
>>> whatever).
>>> 
>>> The next step will be to use hyperNEAT's CPPNs to evolve morphologies for
>>> organisms. I'm thinking of a 3D grid where the CPPN assigns some value to
>>> each cell which defines, according to some threshold, whether a robot goes
>>> in that spot or not. The fitness of the CPPN would be the level of success
>>> in evolving a gait for the resulting shape as described above. Another
>>> method of combining morphology and gait development would be to interleave
>>> them in some way (waves hands).
>>> 
>>> So...does that sound like a good plan, are there any pointers to related
>>> work? Do's and don'ts? Expressions of interest, ridicule or awe?
>>> 
>>> TIA,
>>> 
>>> Evert Haasdijk
>>> VU Amsterdam
>>> 
>> 
> 
>
